## Introduction

The conception of the Advanced Research Projects Agency Network (ARPANET), an early predecessor to the internet, brought with it a litany of questions and debates regarding the role of conflict and security in cyberspace. As the internet developed into a tool of common use, these concerns have only been amplified, sustaining the long-term development of legal, defense, and intelligence frameworks. In fact, one of the first concerns leveled toward ARPANET was a lack of security protocol. In 1972, Willis Ware, an engineer working for the Research and Development (RAND) corporation, released a commissioned report on the challenges of securing information in an open network such as the internet.¹ The first of its kind, the “Ware Report” was declassified seven years later, and is widely considered the foundational document for cybersecurity. In it, Ware lists several items of note for the Defense Science Board, outlining actions and future research focused on resource sharing and “facilitating progress toward handling the open [information] environment”.²

Today, power and conflict within the domain of cyberspace has become even more contentious. The relationship between cyberspace and existing international norms is muddied by its position as a domain of conflict that exists entirely within the information environment.³ Traditionally, the information environment has been the purview of espionage and intelligence

The diversity of tactics available in cyberspace advance at a rapid rate. This constant shift in technological and, by-proxy, environmental conditions challenges the international community’s ability to attribute and respond to harmful acts in cyberspace. Debate is also open on what kinds of activities must be tolerated as the natural costs of competition in this newer domain. The ability to generate outsized effects that might otherwise be too costly indicates that the geopolitical situation of states in competition affects their actions in cyber conflict. Overall, cyberspace violates previously held norms of international relations in ways that often serve to destabilize the current international order at a relatively low cost to the instigating party.⁵

In order to establish where the current international legal consensus is insufficient to divert or absolve conflict in cyberspace, behavioral norms of states and their proxies in cyber conflict must be positioned geopolitically and contextualized through the lens of current theories of international cyber conflict. This mode of analysis of state actors alongside the current state of international law in cyberspace reveals that barriers to attribution preventing retaliatory action might be hurdled by implementing a due diligence standard of data-sharing; streamlining the identification of hostile actors and potentially narrowing the network pathways that hostile actors can use to generate conflict.

Choucri identifies four principles of architecture and management pertinent to the first kind of cyber conflict: the end-to-end argument, the layers principle, network neutrality, and “Code is Law”.

The end-to-end argument and layers principle work together to form cyberspace as it conceptually is. The principle of network neutrality is associated with the architecture of the internet, but reflects an ideological bent, and as such has come to the center of debates regarding access to the open web. network neutrality proposes that the structure of cyberspace should concern itself only with transmission and connectivity, and not interfere with neutral access to any content on the web. An archetypal example of refuting network neutrality is China's Golden Shield project, colloquially known as the "Great Firewall".[15] While the activities of the Golden Shield program are an expression of state power for political control, a different sub-category of cyber conflict; the denial of access to certain cyber-spaces at the transport layer indicates that the PRC opposes or at least disregards the concept of net neutrality as a necessary component of cyberspace.

The final principle of architectural conflicts regarding cyberspace is a dictum that neatly surmises the first three in a neutral package: "Code is Law". Cyberspace is a human-made realm, and the constructed network structure that allows cyberspace to work also determines the limitations of how it can be used. Ultimately, this is a system determined by consensus of real domain actors, and a change in consensus can potentially change the structure of cyberspace as well.[16]

Choucri draws several correlates from these principles of cyber conflict, but the one most relevant to the creation of international law is as follows:

“...The third correlate is the close coupling of politicization in cyberspace with the uses of regulatory instruments that have been effective in kinetic domains. In other words, the increasingly political nature of the cyber domain generally contributes to a growing propensity to use traditional regulatory instruments and leverages.”¹⁷

This correlate signals that as cyberspace is politicized, there is greater opportunity to address conflicts within it through more traditional means, such as treaty or custom. The architectural and managerial principles of cyberspace provide a clear outline of how states can effectively craft international laws of cyberspace: with respect for its layered structure, with clear consensus definitions of neutrality, and with the acknowledgement that changing consensus can change the cyber environment itself.

The widest band of state activity falls into the second category of cyber conflict: conflict for political advantage and profit. There are two major pathways for this type of cyber conflict to affect international relations; cybercrime including espionage, and competitive politics through cyberspace.

A distinction between these two activity types is their visibility. Competitive politics that employ cyberspace to accomplish goals tend to be fairly visible, taking place on the open web and frequently in tandem with real domain activity. Many competitive political strategies that take place in cyberspace utilize visibility as a primary component; either by uplifting the qualities of the acting state, or by displaying the shortcomings and flaws of an opposing state.

The capacity that cyberspace creates for states to escalate competitive actions while maintaining deniability generates the third type of cyber conflict characterized by Choucri: cyber threats to national security.

Cyber threats to national security have been rising exponentially, generated by both cybercrime and competitive politics. This category includes militarization of cyberspace, cyber terrorism, threats to infrastructure and cyberwarfare generally. Most notably, these threats take specific forms based on the first two types of cyber conflict; their structure is limited by the architecture of cyberspace, and their purpose informed by the competitive politics therein. Cyberspace has greatly enhanced the opportunity for states to engage in intelligence competition; the practice of examining and generating actionable intelligence from the open information environment. Globally, Russia utilizes low-level offensive strategies in cyberspace such as misinformation and espionage where more direct offenses would garner severe repercussions. The relative power of Russia’s targets in cyberspace also has a strong corollary with the chosen modes of cyber conflict.³⁹ The Agent.btz incursion is a perfect example of Russia’s selective conflict.

In 2008, an incursion of malware meant to locate and retrieve sensitive information from closed government sites was identified in networks around the world, including the U.S. Department of Defense’s classified intranet.⁴⁰ The incursion was named Agent.btz. The DoD determined that while no sensitive information was retrieved, the progenitor of the malware did have access to said information.

The brilliance of agent.btz was in its function: while it observed the network, it did not retrieve or send classified data at any point; operating more like a periscope into stored classified documents. Because of the quietness of the attack, it took US officials nearly five years to locate and attribute the malware, and only with the additional help of Dutch intelligence services. Often, offenses are carried out by state-sponsored private actors and proxies, further confusing the ability to construct a strategic response. Utilizing sponsored non-state actors also creates jurisdictional barriers that must be overcome by victim states, in terms of seeking reparation.

Even when malware such as this becomes attributable to Russia, it is specifically to groups that do not necessarily meet the standard of government authority for attribution; groups like the Dukes. CozyDuke, known officially as APT(Advanced Persistent Threat)29, is one such group that works to specifically target Executive offices of states opposed to Russia, including the White House and US State Department. Such groups are technically private actors, often financed anonymously and provided instructions through non-cyber backchannels, obscuring attributability further.

## The United States

The ability to obscure attribution doesn’t only serve less powerful nations; it can also be of value to more powerful nations who find themselves in less favorable positions. This often happens to the United States. As the progenitor of the needed network infrastructure for cyberspace activities, the United States maintains a technical advantage as a unipole that must be iterated to be maintained as the conditions of cyberspace evolve.⁴¹ Access to the open web is steadily rising over time, and this advantageous factor is no longer prominent enough to prevent damaging cyber conflict involving the United States.⁴² Preservation of the interests of the United

## Legal Analysis of Case Activity

Despite the many ways that cyberspace allows states in conflict to obfuscate attribution for damaging actions, the standards of attributing a wrongful act remain fairly clear. An internationally wrongful act can be attributed to a state when:

(1) The actor has been empowered with government authority,

and

(2) when the act is taken as an exercise of that government authority.

Cyberspace incentivizes the denial of attribution by altering the cost and effect of international activity in ways that allow states to acquire significant political and economic gain. To the concern of the security and of every nation, incomplete or undecided legal doctrine on cyber conflict provides room for states to block attributability of internationally wrongful acts, avoiding traditional repercussions. Many current standards of international law overlap conceptually with state activity in cyberspace, but do not adequately address how the nature of cyberspace itself affects decision making in this domain.

Through the national profiles of activity in cyberspace, it is clear that states are not necessarily incentivized to work together at the risk of revealing their own activities in cyberspace. Getting powerful nations to dedicate large amounts of resources to stopping cyber conflict will pose a challenge, even though a more stable cyberspace is a communal good. A possible incentive to join in cooperative responses through treaty and custom may be overall exposure to cyber conflicts. Treaties allowing for narrow and specific data access from partner states under certain conditions could serve the purpose of limiting international conflict. Creating data openness between states narrows the pathways that malicious data can travel without detection, heightening the cost of generating harmful effects in cyberspace. ## Introduction
The conception of the Advanced Research Projects Agency Network (ARPANET), an early predecessor to the internet, brought with it a litany of questions and debates regarding the role of conflict and security in cyberspace. As the internet developed into a tool of common use, these concerns have only been amplified, sustaining the long-term development of legal, defense, and intelligence frameworks. In fact, one of the first concerns leveled toward ARPANET was a lack of security protocol. In 1972, Willis Ware, an engineer working for the Research and Development (RAND) corporation, released a commissioned report on the challenges of securing information in an open network such as the internet.¹ The first of its kind, the “Ware Report” was declassified seven years later, and is widely considered the foundational document for cybersecurity. In it, Ware lists several items of note for the Defense Science Board, outlining actions and future research focused on resource sharing and “facilitating progress toward handling the open [information] environment”.²
Today, power and conflict within the domain of cyberspace has become even more contentious. The relationship between cyberspace and existing international norms is muddied by its position as a domain of conflict that exists entirely within the information environment.³ Traditionally, the information environment has been the purview of espionage and intelligence

The diversity of tactics available in cyberspace advance at a rapid rate. This constant shift in technological and, by-proxy, environmental conditions challenges the international community’s ability to attribute and respond to harmful acts in cyberspace. Debate is also open on what kinds of activities must be tolerated as the natural costs of competition in this newer domain. The ability to generate outsized effects that might otherwise be too costly indicates that the geopolitical situation of states in competition affects their actions in cyber conflict. Overall, cyberspace violates previously held norms of international relations in ways that often serve to destabilize the current international order at a relatively low cost to the instigating party.⁵
In order to establish where the current international legal consensus is insufficient to divert or absolve conflict in cyberspace, behavioral norms of states and their proxies in cyber conflict must be positioned geopolitically and contextualized through the lens of current theories of international cyber conflict. This mode of analysis of state actors alongside the current state of international law in cyberspace reveals that barriers to attribution preventing retaliatory action might be hurdled by implementing a due diligence standard of data-sharing; streamlining the identification of hostile actors and potentially narrowing the network pathways that hostile actors can use to generate conflict.
## Project Overview
Interpreting the effects of interstate conflicts in a domain like cyberspace, with the capacity to drastically shift conditions from case-to-case, poses a major challenge to constructing

It presents a description and examination of the current activities of a set of three predominant state powers; The United States, Russia, and China. The case section will frame these states in two ways within the field of international relations and security studies to establish a behavioral archetype of state activity in cyberspace. Firstly, the cases will measure the relative power and trajectory of the states in question, utilizing geostrategic momentum; a comparison of per-capita net resources and the relative success a given state has had in attaining its stated goals.⁶ This measurement will provide insight into how geopolitical context may change the motivations and incentives of powerful states in cyberspace. Secondly, the case study will employ Nazli Choucri’s three categorizations of cyber conflict to define the specific actions of selected states.⁷ Anchored in lateral pressure theory, these categorizations outline the argument that an international coordinated response is necessary to diminish cyber conflict, and helps to delineate which types of conflict in cyberspace could be affected by an international legal response. The goal of such a case comparison is to establish, through consistent and formal analysis,⁸ any cross-case behaviors in cyberspace that come into conflict with the durability of the current international status quo, how these courses of action are chosen, and how these activities obscure themselves from traditional thresholds of attribution in cyber conflict.
The main structural theory that this case study utilizes is the categorization of cyber conflict developed by Nazli Choucri, as an extension of the broader lateral pressure theory.⁹

Choucri characterizes three different categories of international cyber conflict; contentions over the architecture and management of cyberspace, cyber conflict for political advantage and profit, and cyber threats to national security. Architecture and management conflicts take place primarily outside of cyberspace, but state activities within cyberspace are a primary affecting agent in such negotiations, and the results of these contentions can shape the nature of cyberspace as a whole domain. The other two types of cyber conflict are inseparable from the architecture of cyberspace itself, and so any treaties or agreements governing them must account for this first type of cyber conflict, although it takes place in the “real” domain.

## Introduction
The conception of the Advanced Research Projects Agency Network (ARPANET), an early predecessor to the internet, brought with it a litany of questions and debates regarding the role of conflict and security in cyberspace. As the internet developed into a tool of common use, these concerns have only been amplified, sustaining the long-term development of legal, defense, and intelligence frameworks. In fact, one of the first concerns leveled toward ARPANET was a lack of security protocol. In 1972, Willis Ware, an engineer working for the Research and Development (RAND) corporation, released a commissioned report on the challenges of securing information in an open network such as the internet. The first of its kind, the “Ware Report” was declassified seven years later, and is widely considered the foundational document for cybersecurity. In it, Ware lists several items of note for the Defense Science Board, outlining actions and future research focused on resource sharing and “facilitating progress toward handling the open [information] environment”.
Today, power and conflict within the domain of cyberspace has become even more contentious. The relationship between cyberspace and existing international norms is muddied by its position as a domain of conflict that exists entirely within the information environment. Traditionally, the information environment has been the purview of espionage and intelligence

The diversity of tactics available in cyberspace advance at a rapid rate. This constant shift in technological and, by-proxy, environmental conditions challenges the international community’s ability to attribute and respond to harmful acts in cyberspace. Debate is also open on what kinds of activities must be tolerated as the natural costs of competition in this newer domain. The ability to generate outsized effects that might otherwise be too costly indicates that the geopolitical situation of states in competition affects their actions in cyber conflict. Overall, cyberspace violates previously held norms of international relations in ways that often serve to destabilize the current international order at a relatively low cost to the instigating party.
In order to establish where the current international legal consensus is insufficient to divert or absolve conflict in cyberspace, behavioral norms of states and their proxies in cyber conflict must be positioned geopolitically and contextualized through the lens of current theories of international cyber conflict. This mode of analysis of state actors alongside the current state of international law in cyberspace reveals that barriers to attribution preventing retaliatory action might be hurdled by implementing a due diligence standard of data-sharing; streamlining the identification of hostile actors and potentially narrowing the network pathways that hostile actors can use to generate conflict.
## Project Overview
Interpreting the effects of interstate conflicts in a domain like cyberspace, with the capacity to drastically shift conditions from case-to-case, poses a major challenge to constructing

It presents a description and examination of the current activities of a set of three predominant state powers; The United States, Russia, and China. The case section will frame these states in two ways within the field of international relations and security studies to establish a behavioral archetype of state activity in cyberspace. Firstly, the cases will measure the relative power and trajectory of the states in question, utilizing geostrategic momentum; a comparison of per-capita net resources and the relative success a given state has had in attaining its stated goals. This measurement will provide insight into how geopolitical context may change the motivations and incentives of powerful states in cyberspace. Secondly, the case study will employ Nazli Choucri’s three categorizations of cyber conflict to define the specific actions of selected states. Anchored in lateral pressure theory, these categorizations outline the argument that an international coordinated response is necessary to diminish cyber conflict, and helps to delineate which types of conflict in cyberspace could be affected by an international legal response. The goal of such a case comparison is to establish, through consistent and formal analysis, any cross-case behaviors in cyberspace that come into conflict with the durability of the current international status quo, how these courses of action are chosen, and how these activities obscure themselves from traditional thresholds of attribution in cyber conflict.
The main structural theory that this case study utilizes is the categorization of cyber conflict developed by Nazli Choucri, as an extension of the broader lateral pressure theory.

These effects of cyberspace on international relations create an ideal domain for states to engage in political, economic, and other unconventional strategies of conflict that fall below the threshold of warfare; commonly referred to as the “gray zone”. Within the cyberspace gray zone, revisionist actors use the first five features identified by Choucri to inhibit other states from successfully clarifying the final two; Attribution and Accountability. These strategies necessitate an examination of the current conditions of international cyber conflict, and the development of guidelines for establishing cooperative strategies of attribution in this relatively new domain.
Choucri characterizes three different categories of international cyber conflict; contentions over the architecture and management of cyberspace, cyber conflict for political advantage and profit, and cyber threats to national security. Architecture and management conflicts take place primarily outside of cyberspace, but state activities within cyberspace are a primary affecting agent in such negotiations, and the results of these contentions can shape the nature of cyberspace as a whole domain. The other two types of cyber conflict are inseparable from the architecture of cyberspace itself, and so any treaties or agreements governing them must account for this first type of cyber conflict, although it takes place in the “real” domain.

In the context of international lawmaking however, the national security concerns of a state provide a steep incentive that often shape its diplomatic priorities. An assessment of these concerns will inform the discussion of where international law currently fails to address cyber conflict.

The end-to-end argument and layers principle work together to form cyberspace as it conceptually is. End-to-end refers to the layered structure of information passage through the Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol(TCP/IP); namely that communication protocols are justified in the lower layers. This nature of TCP/IP is fundamental to the way cyberspace works, and so begets the layers principle: “the law should respect the integrity of layered Internet architecture.”
These network structures were produced by, and remain dominantly under the control of, American non-profits and the private sector; but the implications of these two principles to a review of current international law are clear. The principle of network neutrality is associated with the architecture of the internet, but reflects an ideological bent, and as such has come to the center of debates regarding access to the open web. network neutrality proposes that the structure of cyberspace should concern itself only with transmission and connectivity, and not interfere with neutral access to any content on the web. This is the principle that receives the most contention from nations outside the United States.
An archetypal example of refuting network neutrality is China's Golden Shield project, colloquially known as the "Great Firewall".[15] While the activities of the Golden Shield program are an expression of state power for political control, a different sub-category of cyber conflict; the denial of access to certain cyber-spaces at the transport layer indicates that the PRC opposes or at least disregards the concept of net neutrality as a necessary component of cyberspace.
The final principle of architectural conflicts regarding cyberspace is a dictum that neatly surmises the first three in a neutral package: "Code is Law". Cyberspace is a human-made realm, and the constructed network structure that allows cyberspace to work also determines the limitations of how it can be used. Ultimately, this is a system determined by consensus of real domain actors, and a change in consensus can potentially change the structure of cyberspace as well.[16]

This correlate signals that as cyberspace is politicized, there is greater opportunity to address conflicts within it through more traditional means, such as treaty or custom. The architectural and managerial principles of cyberspace provide a clear outline of how states can effectively craft international laws of cyberspace: with respect for its layered structure, with clear consensus definitions of neutrality, and with the acknowledgement that changing consensus can change the cyber environment itself.
The widest band of state activity falls into the second category of cyber conflict: conflict for political advantage and profit. There are two major pathways for this type of cyber conflict to affect international relations; cybercrime including espionage, and competitive politics through cyberspace.
A distinction between these two activity types is their visibility. Competitive politics that employ cyberspace to accomplish goals tend to be fairly visible, taking place on the open web and frequently in tandem with real domain activity. Many competitive political strategies that take place in cyberspace utilize visibility as a primary component; either by uplifting the qualities of the acting state, or by displaying the shortcomings and flaws of an opposing state.

The capacity that cyberspace creates for states to escalate competitive actions while maintaining deniability generates the third type of cyber conflict characterized by Choucri: cyber threats to national security.

This category includes militarization of cyberspace, cyber terrorism, threats to infrastructure and cyberwarfare generally. Most notably, these threats take specific forms based on the first two types of cyber conflict; their structure is limited by the architecture of cyberspace, and their purpose informed by the competitive politics therein. ## China

To this end, China’s approach to cyber conflict indicates an acknowledgement of areas where the PRC’s power is most advantageous, such as economy and political influence. Two such examples of China’s activity in cyber conflict include the “Great Firewall”, and “Great Cannon” methods.
China’s Great Firewall is an IP-based national internet boundary that blocks content in opposition to PRC objectives at the “gateway”(Transmission Layer of TCP/IP). This method of national censorship has come under fire as directly oppositional to the principle of network neutrality, and as China has expanded its exposure to western economies and societies, the Great Firewall approach has somewhat broken down and evolved toward individual surveillance under the Golden Shield Project. The Great Firewall and Golden Shield are manifestations of a normative counterargument to network neutrality, referred to casually as “cyber sovereignty”. ## Introduction
The conception of the Advanced Research Projects Agency Network (ARPANET), an early predecessor to the internet, brought with it a litany of questions and debates regarding the role of conflict and security in cyberspace. As the internet developed into a tool of common use, these concerns have only been amplified, sustaining the long-term development of legal, defense, and intelligence frameworks. In fact, one of the first concerns leveled toward ARPANET was a lack of security protocol. In 1972, Willis Ware, an engineer working for the Research and Development (RAND) corporation, released a commissioned report on the challenges of securing information in an open network such as the internet. The first of its kind, the “Ware Report” was declassified seven years later, and is widely considered the foundational document for cybersecurity. In it, Ware lists several items of note for the Defense Science Board, outlining actions and future research focused on resource sharing and “facilitating progress toward handling the open [information] environment”.
Today, power and conflict within the domain of cyberspace has become even more contentious. The relationship between cyberspace and existing international norms is muddied by its position as a domain of conflict that exists entirely within the information environment. Traditionally, the information environment has been the purview of espionage and intelligence

Debate is also open on what kinds of activities must be tolerated as the natural costs of competition in this newer domain. ## Introduction
The conception of the Advanced Research Projects Agency Network (ARPANET), an early predecessor to the internet, brought with it a litany of questions and debates regarding the role of conflict and security in cyberspace. As the internet developed into a tool of common use, these concerns have only been amplified, sustaining the long-term development of legal, defense, and intelligence frameworks. In fact, one of the first concerns leveled toward ARPANET was a lack of security protocol. In 1972, Willis Ware, an engineer working for the Research and Development (RAND) corporation, released a commissioned report on the challenges of securing information in an open network such as the internet. The first of its kind, the “Ware Report” was declassified seven years later, and is widely considered the foundational document for cybersecurity. In it, Ware lists several items of note for the Defense Science Board, outlining actions and future research focused on resource sharing and “facilitating progress toward handling the open [information] environment”.
Today, power and conflict within the domain of cyberspace has become even more contentious. The relationship between cyberspace and existing international norms is muddied by its position as a domain of conflict that exists entirely within the information environment. Traditionally, the information environment has been the purview of espionage and intelligence

operations. While this remains true in cyberspace, the potential for infrastructural, economic, and otherwise material damage through cyber conflict has been thoroughly realized.
The diversity of tactics available in cyberspace advance at a rapid rate. This constant shift in technological and, by-proxy, environmental conditions challenges the international community’s ability to attribute and respond to harmful acts in cyberspace. Debate is also open on what kinds of activities must be tolerated as the natural costs of competition in this newer domain. The ability to generate outsized effects that might otherwise be too costly indicates that the geopolitical situation of states in competition affects their actions in cyber conflict. Overall, cyberspace violates previously held norms of international relations in ways that often serve to destabilize the current international order at a relatively low cost to the instigating party.
In order to establish where the current international legal consensus is insufficient to divert or absolve conflict in cyberspace, behavioral norms of states and their proxies in cyber conflict must be positioned geopolitically and contextualized through the lens of current theories of international cyber conflict. This mode of analysis of state actors alongside the current state of international law in cyberspace reveals that barriers to attribution preventing retaliatory action might be hurdled by implementing a due diligence standard of data-sharing; streamlining the identification of hostile actors and potentially narrowing the network pathways that hostile actors can use to generate conflict.
## Project Overview
Interpreting the effects of interstate conflicts in a domain like cyberspace, with the capacity to drastically shift conditions from case-to-case, poses a major challenge to constructing

a consistent research model. This paper instead takes the approach of a multi-context review. It presents a description and examination of the current activities of a set of three predominant state powers; The United States, Russia, and China. The case section will frame these states in two ways within the field of international relations and security studies to establish a behavioral archetype of state activity in cyberspace. Firstly, the cases will measure the relative power and trajectory of the states in question, utilizing geostrategic momentum; a comparison of per-capita net resources and the relative success a given state has had in attaining its stated goals. This measurement will provide insight into how geopolitical context may change the motivations and incentives of powerful states in cyberspace. Secondly, the case study will employ Nazli Choucri’s three categorizations of cyber conflict to define the specific actions of selected states. Anchored in lateral pressure theory, these categorizations outline the argument that an international coordinated response is necessary to diminish cyber conflict, and helps to delineate which types of conflict in cyberspace could be affected by an international legal response. The goal of such a case comparison is to establish, through consistent and formal analysis, any cross-case behaviors in cyberspace that come into conflict with the durability of the current international status quo, how these courses of action are chosen, and how these activities obscure themselves from traditional thresholds of attribution in cyber conflict.
The main structural theory that this case study utilizes is the categorization of cyber conflict developed by Nazli Choucri, as an extension of the broader lateral pressure theory.

Cyber conflict within lateral pressure theory is contextualized by a state’s propensity to act beyond its established boundaries, and measures this propensity through three driving factors; people, resources, and technology. As stated in an overview of lateral pressure theory:
“As states expand their activities outside territorial boundaries, they encounter other states similarly engaged. Expansion may result in intersections among spheres of influence and set in motion complex interactions that can lead to escalation and conflict – or to cooperation and collaboration – depending on intents and capabilities.”
Under lateral pressure theory, Cyberspace affects international relations in seven different ways:

- Permeation—penetrates boundaries and jurisdictions
- Fluidity—manifests sustained shifts and reconfigurations

- Accountability—bypasses mechanisms of responsibility

Cyberspace affects temporality, providing the potential for most interactions to be instantaneous; physicality, allowing transmission of data in ways that subvert geography and place; permeability, disregarding political borders and legal jurisdictions; fluidity, cyberspace can

adapt its own structure to new contexts; participation, significantly reducing barriers to effective political action; attribution, obscuring the identities of responsible actors including their location; and accountability, cyberspace subverts traditional mechanisms of state responsibility. These effects of cyberspace on international relations create an ideal domain for states to engage in political, economic, and other unconventional strategies of conflict that fall below the threshold of warfare; commonly referred to as the “gray zone”. Within the cyberspace gray zone, revisionist actors use the first five features identified by Choucri to inhibit other states from successfully clarifying the final two; Attribution and Accountability. These strategies necessitate an examination of the current conditions of international cyber conflict, and the development of guidelines for establishing cooperative strategies of attribution in this relatively new domain.
Choucri characterizes three different categories of international cyber conflict; contentions over the architecture and management of cyberspace, cyber conflict for political advantage and profit, and cyber threats to national security. Architecture and management conflicts take place primarily outside of cyberspace, but state activities within cyberspace are a primary affecting agent in such negotiations, and the results of these contentions can shape the nature of cyberspace as a whole domain. The other two types of cyber conflict are inseparable from the architecture of cyberspace itself, and so any treaties or agreements governing them must account for this first type of cyber conflict, although it takes place in the “real” domain.
Cyber conflict for political advantage and profit comprise the widest band of interstate conflict in cyberspace. These conflicts include many national concerns, but “become

As this study is focused particularly on international conflict in cyberspace, it will cover two substrates of cyber conflict for political advantage and profit that have the highest potential to become international: competitive politics via cyber venues, and cybercrime/espionage.
Cyber threats to national security are, according to Choucri, strictly a concern of nations and not necessarily interactive with the international and global system. In the context of international lawmaking however, the national security concerns of a state provide a steep incentive that often shape its diplomatic priorities. An assessment of these concerns will inform the discussion of where international law currently fails to address cyber conflict.

Contentions over architecture and management arise in the real domain as conflicts regarding the way that cyberspace is structured and regulated. Until recently, the United States

hosted many of the organizations that oversee the regulation and structure of cyberspace at-large, but at the state level, the picture is a bit more fragmented. Choucri identifies four principles of architecture and management pertinent to the first kind of cyber conflict: the end-to-end argument, the layers principle, network neutrality, and “Code is Law”.
The end-to-end argument and layers principle work together to form cyberspace as it conceptually is. End-to-end refers to the layered structure of information passage through the Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol(TCP/IP); namely that communication protocols are justified in the lower layers. This nature of TCP/IP is fundamental to the way cyberspace works, and so begets the layers principle: “the law should respect the integrity of layered Internet architecture.”
These network structures were produced by, and remain dominantly under the control of, American non-profits and the private sector; but the implications of these two principles to a review of current international law are clear. Effective multilateral agreements with regard to cyberspace should adequately address the TCP/IP structure by not violating the layered structure, or risk undermining the viability of the network for its intended purpose. This can be most

directly achieved by regulating layers specifically, and applying regulations narrowly to the layers they affect.
The principle of network neutrality is associated with the architecture of the internet, but reflects an ideological bent, and as such has come to the center of debates regarding access to the open web. network neutrality proposes that the structure of cyberspace should concern itself only with transmission and connectivity, and not interfere with neutral access to any content on the web. This is the principle that receives the most contention from nations outside the United States.
An archetypal example of refuting network neutrality is China's Golden Shield project, colloquially known as the "Great Firewall".[15] While the activities of the Golden Shield program are an expression of state power for political control, a different sub-category of cyber conflict; the denial of access to certain cyber-spaces at the transport layer indicates that the PRC opposes or at least disregards the concept of net neutrality as a necessary component of cyberspace.
The final principle of architectural conflicts regarding cyberspace is a dictum that neatly surmises the first three in a neutral package: "Code is Law". Cyberspace is a human-made realm, and the constructed network structure that allows cyberspace to work also determines the limitations of how it can be used. Ultimately, this is a system determined by consensus of real domain actors, and a change in consensus can potentially change the structure of cyberspace as well.[16]

Choucri draws several correlates from these principles of cyber conflict, but the one most relevant to the creation of international law is as follows:
“...The third correlate is the close coupling of politicization in cyberspace with the uses of regulatory instruments that have been effective in kinetic domains. In other words, the increasingly political nature of the cyber domain generally contributes to a growing propensity to use traditional regulatory instruments and leverages.”
This correlate signals that as cyberspace is politicized, there is greater opportunity to address conflicts within it through more traditional means, such as treaty or custom. The architectural and managerial principles of cyberspace provide a clear outline of how states can effectively craft international laws of cyberspace: with respect for its layered structure, with clear consensus definitions of neutrality, and with the acknowledgement that changing consensus can change the cyber environment itself.
The widest band of state activity falls into the second category of cyber conflict: conflict for political advantage and profit. There are two major pathways for this type of cyber conflict to affect international relations; cybercrime including espionage, and competitive politics through cyberspace.
A distinction between these two activity types is their visibility. Competitive politics that employ cyberspace to accomplish goals tend to be fairly visible, taking place on the open web and frequently in tandem with real domain activity. Many competitive political strategies that take place in cyberspace utilize visibility as a primary component; either by uplifting the qualities of the acting state, or by displaying the shortcomings and flaws of an opposing state.

Cybercrime and espionage, on the other hand, by its very nature incorporates efforts to remain clandestine while generating political or economic gain for the actor. This type of activity can include using cyberspace to spy; hacking into government databases to retrieve classified information. It can also include the discreet theft of intellectual property, and the corruption of competitor states' information networks.
While a distinguishing factor between competitive politics and cybercrime/espionage is visibility, both share features that challenge a nation's ability to attribute these activities. A hostile actor may transmit data through the network infrastructure of third-party states in order to disguise the origin of cybercrime, or call upon a foreign asset to publish propaganda from a distant geographic location, offering a means of obscuring the propaganda's source. The capacity that cyberspace creates for states to escalate competitive actions while maintaining deniability generates the third type of cyber conflict characterized by Choucri: cyber threats to national security.
Cyber threats to national security have been rising exponentially, generated by both cybercrime and competitive politics. This category includes militarization of cyberspace, cyber terrorism, threats to infrastructure and cyberwarfare generally. Most notably, these threats take specific forms based on the first two types of cyber conflict; their structure is limited by the architecture of cyberspace, and their purpose informed by the competitive politics therein. Cyber threats to national security are felt widely and are coming from all over the world, leveraging the permeability of cyberspace and its disregard for political borders.[18] In order to maintain cyberspace as a normative domain of international relations, while diminishing cyber threats to national security, a coordinated international response is necessary and may be facilitated

This measurement aligns with the lateral pressure framework of observing people, resources, and technology to draw its conclusions. Cyberspace has greatly enhanced the opportunity for states to engage in intelligence competition; the practice of examining and generating actionable intelligence from the open information environment. ## Introduction
The conception of the Advanced Research Projects Agency Network (ARPANET), an early predecessor to the internet, brought with it a litany of questions and debates regarding the role of conflict and security in cyberspace. As the internet developed into a tool of common use, these concerns have only been amplified, sustaining the long-term development of legal, defense, and intelligence frameworks. In fact, one of the first concerns leveled toward ARPANET was a lack of security protocol. In 1972, Willis Ware, an engineer working for the Research and Development (RAND) corporation, released a commissioned report on the challenges of securing information in an open network such as the internet.¹ The first of its kind, the “Ware Report” was declassified seven years later, and is widely considered the foundational document for cybersecurity. In it, Ware lists several items of note for the Defense Science Board, outlining actions and future research focused on resource sharing and “facilitating progress toward handling the open [information] environment”.²
Today, power and conflict within the domain of cyberspace has become even more contentious. The relationship between cyberspace and existing international norms is muddied by its position as a domain of conflict that exists entirely within the information environment.³ Traditionally, the information environment has been the purview of espionage and intelligence

The diversity of tactics available in cyberspace advance at a rapid rate. This constant shift in technological and, by-proxy, environmental conditions challenges the international community’s ability to attribute and respond to harmful acts in cyberspace. Debate is also open on what kinds of activities must be tolerated as the natural costs of competition in this newer domain. The ability to generate outsized effects that might otherwise be too costly indicates that the geopolitical situation of states in competition affects their actions in cyber conflict. Overall, cyberspace violates previously held norms of international relations in ways that often serve to destabilize the current international order at a relatively low cost to the instigating party.⁵
In order to establish where the current international legal consensus is insufficient to divert or absolve conflict in cyberspace, behavioral norms of states and their proxies in cyber conflict must be positioned geopolitically and contextualized through the lens of current theories of international cyber conflict. This mode of analysis of state actors alongside the current state of international law in cyberspace reveals that barriers to attribution preventing retaliatory action might be hurdled by implementing a due diligence standard of data-sharing; streamlining the identification of hostile actors and potentially narrowing the network pathways that hostile actors can use to generate conflict.

The debate on this question has been mostly delayed, due in part to the obfuscation of attributability.⁴⁸ While the attack has been all but traced back to the United States and its allies, clever use of cooperative regional proxies and obfuscatory tactics that the US had itself been victim of in the past has kept true accountability for Stuxnet out of reach.
A major concern with the implementation of Stuxnet is that it may offer legitimacy to tactics that are ultimately harmful to a cooperative mitigation of cyber threats to national security. Lending credence to tactics that deny attribution is a high-risk strategy for the United States to undertake, and may not serve to maintain their current level of dominance in the cyber domain, given the relationship between these types of conflict and the national security threats they generate.
## Legal Analysis of Case Activity
Despite the many ways that cyberspace allows states in conflict to obfuscate attribution for damaging actions, the standards of attributing a wrongful act remain fairly clear. An internationally wrongful act can be attributed to a state when:
(1) The actor has been empowered with government authority,
and
(2) when the act is taken as an exercise of that government authority.
The North Atlantic Treaty Organization CCDCOE Cyber Law Toolkit notes that

Turner 22
"An internationally wrongful act can be attributed to a state if it was carried out by organs of the state, persons or entities empowered to exercise elements of governmental authority on behalf of that state, or agents acting on the instructions of, or under the direction or control of the state; or where the state acknowledges and adopts the act as its own."⁴⁹ ⁵⁰
Cyberspace incentivizes the denial of attribution by altering the cost and effect of international activity in ways that allow states to acquire significant political and economic gain. To the concern of the security and of every nation, incomplete or undecided legal doctrine on cyber conflict provides room for states to block attributability of internationally wrongful acts, avoiding traditional repercussions. Many current standards of international law overlap conceptually with state activity in cyberspace, but do not adequately address how the nature of cyberspace itself affects decision making in this domain.
Through the national profiles of activity in cyberspace, it is clear that states are not necessarily incentivized to work together at the risk of revealing their own activities in cyberspace. Getting powerful nations to dedicate large amounts of resources to stopping cyber conflict will pose a challenge, even though a more stable cyberspace is a communal good. A possible incentive to join in cooperative responses through treaty and custom may be overall exposure to cyber conflicts. Further study on specific measurable variables that could trace a given state's exposure to cyber conflict of any or all types is available through Choucri's work, and developing these measurements could help tailor specific incentive options for nations to collaborate on treaties addressing cyber conflict attribution.

One current recommendation is that these gaps may be managed through a heightened due diligence standard; holding states responsible as proxy legal-persons for the data their infrastructure transmits. The implications of heightened responsibility of due diligence standards contains its own compelling set of challenges.⁵¹ An alternative may be to expedite the attribution process by creating an enhanced standard of cooperation through heightened due diligence specifically toward transmitted data; not as a means of attribution for aiding and abetting data transfer, but instead as a means to accelerate the process of accurately attributing the origin state of the offending action. Agreements to share public TCP/IP data with friendly nations respects the Layer Principle and doesn’t interfere with the End-to-End argument. Sharing residual data only addresses the transport layer of TCP/IP, and can be done without inhibiting access or transmission.
Treaties allowing for narrow and specific data access from partner states under certain conditions could serve the purpose of limiting international conflict. Additionally, robust data-sharing agreements could narrow the possible pathways malicious data might take to arrive at its target, creating overall narrower channels of deduction for the harmed state. Creating data openness between states narrows the pathways that malicious data can travel without detection, heightening the cost of generating harmful effects in cyberspace. Enough nations doing so can create a “dragnet” effect, accelerating the attribution of malicious actors who would utilize public networks. Such an effect could cool cyber conflicts overall, by addressing the core incentive toward cyber conflict by heightening the initial costs to actors who would hope to remain anonymous.

## Introduction
The conception of the Advanced Research Projects Agency Network (ARPANET), an early predecessor to the internet, brought with it a litany of questions and debates regarding the role of conflict and security in cyberspace. As the internet developed into a tool of common use, these concerns have only been amplified, sustaining the long-term development of legal, defense, and intelligence frameworks. In fact, one of the first concerns leveled toward ARPANET was a lack of security protocol. In 1972, Willis Ware, an engineer working for the Research and Development (RAND) corporation, released a commissioned report on the challenges of securing information in an open network such as the internet.¹ The first of its kind, the “Ware Report” was declassified seven years later, and is widely considered the foundational document for cybersecurity. In it, Ware lists several items of note for the Defense Science Board, outlining actions and future research focused on resource sharing and “facilitating progress toward handling the open [information] environment”.²
Today, power and conflict within the domain of cyberspace has become even more contentious. The relationship between cyberspace and existing international norms is muddied by its position as a domain of conflict that exists entirely within the information environment.³ Traditionally, the information environment has been the purview of espionage and intelligence

operations.⁴ While this remains true in cyberspace, the potential for infrastructural, economic, and otherwise material damage through cyber conflict has been thoroughly realized.
The diversity of tactics available in cyberspace advance at a rapid rate. This constant shift in technological and, by-proxy, environmental conditions challenges the international community’s ability to attribute and respond to harmful acts in cyberspace. Debate is also open on what kinds of activities must be tolerated as the natural costs of competition in this newer domain. The ability to generate outsized effects that might otherwise be too costly indicates that the geopolitical situation of states in competition affects their actions in cyber conflict. Overall, cyberspace violates previously held norms of international relations in ways that often serve to destabilize the current international order at a relatively low cost to the instigating party.⁵
In order to establish where the current international legal consensus is insufficient to divert or absolve conflict in cyberspace, behavioral norms of states and their proxies in cyber conflict must be positioned geopolitically and contextualized through the lens of current theories of international cyber conflict. This mode of analysis of state actors alongside the current state of international law in cyberspace reveals that barriers to attribution preventing retaliatory action might be hurdled by implementing a due diligence standard of data-sharing; streamlining the identification of hostile actors and potentially narrowing the network pathways that hostile actors can use to generate conflict.
## Project Overview
Interpreting the effects of interstate conflicts in a domain like cyberspace, with the capacity to drastically shift conditions from case-to-case, poses a major challenge to constructing

a consistent research model. This paper instead takes the approach of a multi-context review. It presents a description and examination of the current activities of a set of three predominant state powers; The United States, Russia, and China. The case section will frame these states in two ways within the field of international relations and security studies to establish a behavioral archetype of state activity in cyberspace. Firstly, the cases will measure the relative power and trajectory of the states in question, utilizing geostrategic momentum; a comparison of per-capita net resources and the relative success a given state has had in attaining its stated goals.⁶ This measurement will provide insight into how geopolitical context may change the motivations and incentives of powerful states in cyberspace. Secondly, the case study will employ Nazli Choucri’s three categorizations of cyber conflict to define the specific actions of selected states.⁷ Anchored in lateral pressure theory, these categorizations outline the argument that an international coordinated response is necessary to diminish cyber conflict, and helps to delineate which types of conflict in cyberspace could be affected by an international legal response. The goal of such a case comparison is to establish, through consistent and formal analysis,⁸ any cross-case behaviors in cyberspace that come into conflict with the durability of the current international status quo, how these courses of action are chosen, and how these activities obscure themselves from traditional thresholds of attribution in cyber conflict.
The main structural theory that this case study utilizes is the categorization of cyber conflict developed by Nazli Choucri, as an extension of the broader lateral pressure theory.⁹

Cyber conflict within lateral pressure theory is contextualized by a state’s propensity to act beyond its established boundaries, and measures this propensity through three driving factors; people, resources, and technology. As stated in an overview of lateral pressure theory:
“As states expand their activities outside territorial boundaries, they encounter other states similarly engaged. Expansion may result in intersections among spheres of influence and set in motion complex interactions that can lead to escalation and conflict – or to cooperation and collaboration – depending on intents and capabilities.”¹⁰

Cyberspace affects temporality, providing the potential for most interactions to be instantaneous; physicality, allowing transmission of data in ways that subvert geography and place; permeability, disregarding political borders and legal jurisdictions; fluidity, cyberspace can

Turner 5
adapt its own structure to new contexts; participation, significantly reducing barriers to effective political action; attribution, obscuring the identities of responsible actors including their location; and accountability, cyberspace subverts traditional mechanisms of state responsibility.¹¹ These effects of cyberspace on international relations create an ideal domain for states to engage in political, economic, and other unconventional strategies of conflict that fall below the threshold of warfare; commonly referred to as the “gray zone”.¹² Within the cyberspace gray zone, revisionist actors use the first five features identified by Choucri to inhibit other states from successfully clarifying the final two; Attribution and Accountability. These strategies necessitate an examination of the current conditions of international cyber conflict, and the development of guidelines for establishing cooperative strategies of attribution in this relatively new domain.
Choucri characterizes three different categories of international cyber conflict; contentions over the architecture and management of cyberspace, cyber conflict for political advantage and profit, and cyber threats to national security. Architecture and management conflicts take place primarily outside of cyberspace, but state activities within cyberspace are a primary affecting agent in such negotiations, and the results of these contentions can shape the nature of cyberspace as a whole domain. The other two types of cyber conflict are inseparable from the architecture of cyberspace itself, and so any treaties or agreements governing them must account for this first type of cyber conflict, although it takes place in the “real” domain.
Cyber conflict for political advantage and profit comprise the widest band of interstate conflict in cyberspace. These conflicts include many national concerns, but “become

Cyber threats to national security are, according to Choucri, strictly a concern of nations and not necessarily interactive with the international and global system. In the context of international lawmaking however, the national security concerns of a state provide a steep incentive that often shape its diplomatic priorities. An assessment of these concerns will inform the discussion of where international law currently fails to address cyber conflict.

Contentions over architecture and management arise in the real domain as conflicts regarding the way that cyberspace is structured and regulated. Until recently, the United States

hosted many of the organizations that oversee the regulation and structure of cyberspace at-large, but at the state level, the picture is a bit more fragmented. Choucri identifies four principles of architecture and management pertinent to the first kind of cyber conflict: the end-to-end argument, the layers principle, network neutrality, and “Code is Law”.
The end-to-end argument and layers principle work together to form cyberspace as it conceptually is. End-to-end refers to the layered structure of information passage through the Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol(TCP/IP); namely that communication protocols are justified in the lower layers. This nature of TCP/IP is fundamental to the way cyberspace works, and so begets the layers principle: “the law should respect the integrity of layered Internet architecture.”¹⁴
These network structures were produced by, and remain dominantly under the control of, American non-profits and the private sector; but the implications of these two principles to a review of current international law are clear. Effective multilateral agreements with regard to cyberspace should adequately address the TCP/IP structure by not violating the layered structure, or risk undermining the viability of the network for its intended purpose. This can be most

directly achieved by regulating layers specifically, and applying regulations narrowly to the layers they affect.
The principle of network neutrality is associated with the architecture of the internet, but reflects an ideological bent, and as such has come to the center of debates regarding access to the open web. network neutrality proposes that the structure of cyberspace should concern itself only with transmission and connectivity, and not interfere with neutral access to any content on the web. This is the principle that receives the most contention from nations outside the United States.
An archetypal example of refuting network neutrality is China's Golden Shield project, colloquially known as the "Great Firewall".[15] While the activities of the Golden Shield program are an expression of state power for political control, a different sub-category of cyber conflict; the denial of access to certain cyber-spaces at the transport layer indicates that the PRC opposes or at least disregards the concept of net neutrality as a necessary component of cyberspace.
The final principle of architectural conflicts regarding cyberspace is a dictum that neatly surmises the first three in a neutral package: "Code is Law". Cyberspace is a human-made realm, and the constructed network structure that allows cyberspace to work also determines the limitations of how it can be used. Ultimately, this is a system determined by consensus of real domain actors, and a change in consensus can potentially change the structure of cyberspace as well.[16]

Turner 9
Choucri draws several correlates from these principles of cyber conflict, but the one most relevant to the creation of international law is as follows:
“...The third correlate is the close coupling of politicization in cyberspace with the uses of regulatory instruments that have been effective in kinetic domains. In other words, the increasingly political nature of the cyber domain generally contributes to a growing propensity to use traditional regulatory instruments and leverages.”¹⁷
This correlate signals that as cyberspace is politicized, there is greater opportunity to address conflicts within it through more traditional means, such as treaty or custom. The architectural and managerial principles of cyberspace provide a clear outline of how states can effectively craft international laws of cyberspace: with respect for its layered structure, with clear consensus definitions of neutrality, and with the acknowledgement that changing consensus can change the cyber environment itself.
The widest band of state activity falls into the second category of cyber conflict: conflict for political advantage and profit. There are two major pathways for this type of cyber conflict to affect international relations; cybercrime including espionage, and competitive politics through cyberspace.
A distinction between these two activity types is their visibility. Competitive politics that employ cyberspace to accomplish goals tend to be fairly visible, taking place on the open web and frequently in tandem with real domain activity. Many competitive political strategies that take place in cyberspace utilize visibility as a primary component; either by uplifting the qualities of the acting state, or by displaying the shortcomings and flaws of an opposing state.
¹⁷ Choucri, N. (2012). Cyberpolitics in International Relations. The MIT Press. http://www.jstor.org/stable/j.ctt5hhkrs
Turner 10
Cybercrime and espionage, on the other hand, by its very nature incorporates efforts to remain clandestine while generating political or economic gain for the actor. This type of activity can include using cyberspace to spy; hacking into government databases to retrieve classified information. It can also include the discreet theft of intellectual property, and the corruption of competitor states' information networks.
While a distinguishing factor between competitive politics and cybercrime/espionage is visibility, both share features that challenge a nation's ability to attribute these activities. A hostile actor may transmit data through the network infrastructure of third-party states in order to disguise the origin of cybercrime, or call upon a foreign asset to publish propaganda from a distant geographic location, offering a means of obscuring the propaganda's source. The capacity that cyberspace creates for states to escalate competitive actions while maintaining deniability generates the third type of cyber conflict characterized by Choucri: cyber threats to national security.
Cyber threats to national security have been rising exponentially, generated by both cybercrime and competitive politics. This category includes militarization of cyberspace, cyber terrorism, threats to infrastructure and cyberwarfare generally. Most notably, these threats take specific forms based on the first two types of cyber conflict; their structure is limited by the architecture of cyberspace, and their purpose informed by the competitive politics therein. Cyber threats to national security are felt widely and are coming from all over the world, leveraging the permeability of cyberspace and its disregard for political borders.[18] In order to maintain cyberspace as a normative domain of international relations, while diminishing cyber threats to national security, a coordinated international response is necessary and may be facilitated

Turner 11
through developing the international laws of cyberspace.
In keeping with Choucri's description of cyber conflict, the case section contextualizes the geopolitical position of each nation studied, using a measurement of power and trajectory called "Geostrategic Momentum". This measurement aligns with the lateral pressure framework of observing people, resources, and technology to draw its conclusions. International relations scholar Dani Belo has proposed a means of measuring the strategic actions of states over time by comparing socio-economic patterns with the level of success a nation has achieved relative to
Turner 12
their stated goals.¹⁹ Belo grounds this framework of “geostrategic momentum” in a hybrid approach to measuring power first developed by Michael Beckley and later revisited by Caleb Pomeroy, measuring both net resources and expenses per-capita, weighing these measurements against outcomes over time to determine a nation’s relative power.²⁰ ²¹ These measurements are expressed by placing a nation’s “actual role” globally in juxtaposition with its “ideal role” based on its net per-capita resources and frequency of successful foreign policy actions.
An additional consideration that these case studies must make is that some less intensive types of cyber conflict are not necessarily the subject of international law. Cyberspace has greatly enhanced the opportunity for states to engage in intelligence competition; the practice of examining and generating actionable intelligence from the open information environment. This activity, while competitive and generative of conflict, is broadly accepted by states as an inherent cost to information sharing. When determining which activities necessitate a cooperative international legal response, an examination of how cyber conflict exceeds the bounds of acceptable competition must be undertaken.²² Such examinations indicate that the primary means through which cyber conflict exceeds the upper threshold of intelligence competition is the ability to generate large detrimental or deterrent effects at very little cost; a resource-asymmetry that has significant practical implications for competing states.²³

Turner 13
State actors that seek to revise the international order may take bolder actions in cyberspace as a domain of conflict with a higher asymmetry of cost to effect. Costs of information gathering are greatly reduced through networked computer systems, both closed and open. These states and their pseudo- or non- state proxies may also readily launch low-level attacks such as disinformation campaigns without incurring the same disruptive costs that a military psychological operation or traditional propaganda effort may incur. instances of infrastructural sabotage, such as the disruption and denial of telecom and financial transaction services through malware and distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks, also provide directly damaging options to states at very little cost comparable to similar courses of action.²⁴ The same principle of low-cost information warfare applies to more powerful states, when the other conditions of competition are less favorable.
Belo’s measurement of geostrategic momentum characterizes the motivations of state actors, and Choucri’s categorization of cyber conflicts outlines the need for cooperative international responses, and frames the structural limitations of any such response. Taken together through focused case comparisons, an international legal response that can effectively attribute actions harmful cyber conflict may emerge.
## Cases
## China
In parallel with the chronological development of cyberspace as a domain of international conflict, China has held a steeply ascendant trajectory in nearly every realm of state power.²⁵ As the primary political and economic rival of the United States, China holds advantages that loom large over the question of unipolarity. Namely, China’s actual global role is much smaller than its
²⁴ Clarke, R.A.; Knake, R.K. (2010). Cyber War: The Next Threat To National Security And What To Do About It. Harper Collins.
²⁵ Joseph, W. A. (2019). Politics in China: An introduction. Oxford University Press.
Turner 14
potential role, by a margin similar to the inverse of the United States (whose actual role tends to exceed its ideal potential role).²⁶
This potentiality gap provides opportunity to move more slowly than other nations with revisionist intent; utilizing a multiplicity of low-level conflict to subvert the option of open warfare with their great-power rival. Notably, military power remains one area where the United States maintains a clearly superior capacity. To this end, China’s approach to cyber conflict indicates an acknowledgement of areas where the PRC’s power is most advantageous, such as economy and political influence.²⁷ Two such examples of China’s activity in cyber conflict include the “Great Firewall”, and “Great Cannon” methods.
China’s Great Firewall is an IP-based national internet boundary that blocks content in opposition to PRC objectives at the “gateway”(Transmission Layer of TCP/IP). This method of national censorship has come under fire as directly oppositional to the principle of network neutrality, and as China has expanded its exposure to western economies and societies, the Great Firewall approach has somewhat broken down and evolved toward individual surveillance under the Golden Shield Project. The Great Firewall and Golden Shield are manifestations of a normative counterargument to network neutrality, referred to casually as “cyber sovereignty”.²⁸ This opposition to network neutrality falls firmly under the first type of Choucri’s categories of cyber conflict; conflict regarding the architecture and management of cyberspace. In light of heavy domestic and international opposition to the PRC’s conception of cyber sovereignty, China

has shifted its approach away from blanket censorship and toward individual and organizational surveillance and offensive measures, leaning more toward cyber conflict for political gain; specifically obstructive cybercrime.
The Great Cannon method of attack reflects this shift toward individual targeting over mass censorship. The Great Cannon is a program that allows its user to inject malware into internet traffic passing through the Great Firewall. It leverages the massive internet user base in China to generate nearly insurmountable distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks; effectively closing down targeted websites. In March 2015, the non-profit Great Fire, which assists citizens of China in circumventing the Great Firewall, was targeted by the Great Cannon. (1) The actor has been empowered with government authority,
and
(2) when the act is taken as an exercise of that government authority.
